A cross reference of related application
This application is a continuation-in-part application of PCT/US 98/No. 04489 for which it applied as of March 6, 1998.

The background of invention
This invention relates to the process and intermediate body for preparing a novel steroid derivative and these compounds.

The several compound which associates to outside-film|membrane of Gram-negative bacteria strongly destroying outside-film|membrane, and making permeability|transmittance increase is known.
A pervious|transmissive increase may make the sensitivity with respect to the other antibiotics of Gram-negative bacteria increase.
It is polymyxin antibiotics which research is following most with this type of compound.
The example of the test which investigates the coupling|bonding of the polymyxin B with respect to structural components with main outside-film|membrane of Gram-negative bacteria (lipid A),
D.C. Refer Morrison & Jacobus (D.C. Morrison and D. M. Jacobs), "joint (Binding of Polymixin B to The Lipid a Portion of Bacterial Lipopolysaccharides) of the polymyxin B with respect to the lipid which is a part of bacteria lipopolysaccharide", a Immunochemistry 1976, 13 volume, and 813-819.
Regarding the example of the test including the coupling|bonding of the polymyxin derivative|guide_body with respect to Gram-negative bacteria,
M. Refer ƒoƒAƒ‰ &P. ƒrƒ‹ƒ„ƒlƒ“ (M. Vaara and P. Viljanen), "joint (Binding of Polymyxin B Nonapeptide to Gram-negative Bacteria) of the polymyxin B nonapeptide with respect to Gram-negative bacteria", a Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, 1985, 27 volume, and 548-554.

The film|membrane of Gram-negative bacteria is a semipermeable|semi-transmissive molecule|numerator "sieve" which restrict|limits access of the antibiotics with respect to the target in a bacteria cell, and a host defense molecule|numerator.
Thus, the cation which can interact with the pervious|transmissive barrier of outside-film|membrane and can decompose|disassemble it, and the poly cation can make the sensitivity of antibiotics and the Gram-negative-bacterium venereal-disease original microbe with respect to a host defense molecule|numerator increase.
The Hancock & one (Hancock and Wong) made the name a "permeation|transmission agent", in order to authenticate that an extensive peptide can permeate|transmit a pervious|transmissive barrier and to describe them.
(The Hancock & one (Hancock and Wong), Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 26:48, 1984).

The term "condensed ring" used in this specification,
Preferably it can become a heterocyclic ring or a carbocyclic ring.

The term the "saturation" used in this specification points out condensed ring of the formula I which each atom in condensed ring is hydrogen as the valence of each atom is satisfy|filled, or is substituted.
The term "unsubstitution" used in this specification points out the part by which each atom is hydrogenated as the valence of each atom is satisfy|filled.
The term "halo" used in this specification points out a halogen atom like a fluorine, chlorine, a bromine, or an iodine.

Although H (glycine), methyl (alanine), -CH2-(C=O)-NH2 (asparagine), -CH2-SH (cysteine), and -CH(OH) CH3 (threonine) are contained in the example of an amino acid side chain, it does not limit to these.

An alkyl group is a branched or non-branched hydrocarbon which may be substituted or unsubstituted.
Isopropyl, sec-butyl, isobutyl, tert- butyl, sec -pentyl-, an isopentyl, tert- pentyl, isohexyl is contained in the example of a branched alkyl group.
A substituted alkyl group may have 1 and a 2, 3 or more substituent, they may be same or different, and each substitutes a hydrogen atom.
Substituents are a halogen (for example, F, Cl, Br, and I), hydroxyl, the protected hydroxyl, amino, the protected amino, a carboxy, the protected carboxy, cyano, methylsulfonyl amino, alkoxy, acyloxy, nitro, and lower haloalkyl.

The term the "substitution" used in this specification points out 1, 2, and the part that has a 3 or more substituent by which it may be same or different and each substitutes a hydrogen atom.
Although a halogen (for example, F, Cl, Br, and I), hydroxyl, the protected hydroxyl, amino, the protected amino, a carboxy, the protected carboxy, cyano, methylsulfonyl amino, alkoxy, alkyl, aryl, aralkyl, acyloxy, nitro, and lower haloalkyl are contained in the example of a substituent, it does not limit to these.

An aryl group is a C6-20 aromatic ring in which a ring is comprised with the carbon atom (For example, a C6-14, C6-10 aryl group).
Fluoromethyl, dichloro methyl, a trifluoromethyl, 1, 1- difluoroethyl, and 2, 2- dibromo ethyl is contained in the example of haloalkyl.

An aralkyl group is group which has at least 1 alkyl or alkylene chain couple|bonded with at least 1 aryl ring and its ring and containing C6-C20.
An example of an aralkyl group is a benzyl group.

A bonding group is a bivalent part used in order to combine another steroid, for example, the 2nd compound of the formula I, and the compound of a formula.
The example of a bonding group is (C1-C10) alkyloxy (C1-C10) alkyl.

Many amino protecting groups are known at this technical field.
Generally, the kind of protecting group has stable it with respect to some subsequent reaction conditions in the other position of a compound,
Comprising:
It is not important as long as it can remove|eliminate at the suitable time, without exerting harmful|toxic influence with respect to the remainder of a molecule|numerator.
Furthermore, after substantial synthetic conversion is complete|finished, you may substitute a protecting group by another group.
The compound is contained in this invention when a certain compound differs from the compound of an indication evidently only within the point that the 1 or more protecting group of the compound of an indication is substituted by a different protecting group.
The further Example and conditions are shown by T. W. green (T. W. Greene), "protecting group (Protective Groups in Organic Chemistry) in an organic chemistry", and (the 1st edition, 1981 and 2nd plate|version|printing 1991).

This invention includes the method of synthesize|combining the compound of the formula I, when at least 2 of R1-R14 is also selected from the group which consists independently of substituted or unsubstituted (C1-C10) aminoalkyl oxy.
This method includes the step which the compound of formula IV is made to contact:
In formula, at least 2 of R1-R14 is hydroxyl,
The remaining part on the condensed ring A, B, and C and D is defined to the formula I,
An electrophilic agent produces the alkyl ether compound of formula IV, and, in Formula, at least 2 of R1-R14 is (C1-C10) alkyloxy.
The alkyl ether compound is converted into the amino precursor compound selected from the group which at least 2 of R1-R14 becomes independently from (C1-C10) azide alkyloxy and (C1-C10) cyano alkyloxy,
An amino precursor compound is reduce|restored and the compound of the formula I is formed.

Although a 2-(2-bromo- ethyl) -1,3- dioxolane, 2-iodoacetamide, the 2-chloro- acetamide, N-(2-bromo- ethyl) phthalimide, N-(3-bromo- propyl) phthalimide, and the allyl|allele bromide is contained in the electrophilic agent used in this method, it does not limit to these.
A preferable electrophilic agent is the allyl|allele bromide.

This invention includes the method at least 2 of R1-R14 also manufactures the compound of the formula I which is (C1-C10) guanido alkyloxy.
This method makes the compound of formula IV whose at least 2 of R1-R14 is hydroxyl contact an electrophilic agent.
At least 2 of R1-R14 includes producing the alkyl ether compound of formula IV which is (C1-C10) alkyloxy.
An allylether compound is converted into the amino precursor compound in which at least 2 of R1-R14 is independently selected from the group which consists of (C1-C10) azide alkyloxy and (C1-C10) cyano alkyloxy.
An amino precursor compound is reduce|restored and at least 2 of R1-R14 produces the aminoalkyl ether compound which is (C1-C10) aminoalkyl oxy.
When an aminoalkyl ether compound is made to contact with a guanidino production|generation electrophilic agent, the compound of the formula I will be produced|generated.

The term the "guanidino production|generation electrophilic agent" used in this specification points out the electrophilic agent used in order to produce|generate the guanidino compound of the formula I.
The example of a guanidino production|generation electrophilic agent is HSO3-C(NH)-NH2.

At least 2 of R1-R14 is H2 N-HC(Q5) -C(O)-O-, and this invention also includes the method Q5 manufactures the compound of the formula I which is a side chain of arbitrary amino acids.
A method makes the compound of formula IV whose at least 2 of R1-R14 is hydroxyl contact with the protected amino acid.
At least 2 of R1-R14 is P. G. -HN-HC(Q5)-C(O)-O-,
Q5 is a side chain of arbitrary amino acids,
P. G. includes the step which produces the amino acid compound which is an amino protecting group, and from which formula IV was protected.
When the protecting group of the protected amino acid compound remove|deviates, the compound of the formula I will be produced.

This invention also contains an important pharmacological composition useful as an antibacterial agent, the bacteria sensitization agent with respect to other antibiotics, and a bacteria destruction-of-membrane agent.
A pharmacological composition can be used in order to treat the human and animal which have a bacterial infection.
The pharmacological composition can contain the effective dose of a steroid derivative in combination with individual or another antibacterial agent.

This invention contains the compound which has a ring system of at least 4 condensed ring, and also has 5-7 atoms of this each rings.
A ring system has two surfaces and contains three chain|strands couple|bonded with the same surface.

The azide was reduce|restored by treating the tri azide (0.11 g, 0.15 mmol) with THF (10 ml) of Ph3P(0.20 g, 0.77 mmol), and an H2O (1 ml) solution.
Three days of liquid mixture were stirred.
When the solvent was removed under vacuum and the silica gel chromatography (CH2Cl2/MeOH/28%NH3*H2O, 12:6:1, next 10:5:1.5) refine|purified residue, the desired product was acquired as glass (0.077 g, yield 78%).
When the Et2O(1 M, 0.5 ml) solution of HCl was added to glass, the corresponding HCl salt was obtained.

Compound 133
The mesylate (0.19 g, 0.264 mmol) originating in 23 was stirred at 80 degreeC with an excessive quantity of octyl amines (2 ml) for 12 hours.
After removing an octyl amine under vacuum, when the chromatography (2-%Et3N is added to a silica gel, EtOAc/hexane, and 1:4.) of residue was performed, the desired product was acquired as pale yellow oil (0.19 g, yield 95%).
The tri azide (0.18 g, 0.239 mmol) was melt|dissolved in THF (10 ml) and EtOH (10 ml).
The Lindlar catalyst (44 mg) was added and suspension was shaken under H2 (50 psi) for 12 hours.
After removing a solvent under vacuum, the silica gel chromatography (It is 10:5:1.5 to CH2Cl2/MeOH/28%NH3*H2O, 10:5:1, and the next.) refine|purified residue.
Et2O (it is 2 times about 10 ml) extracted the transparent solution obtained by adding 1 M HCl (2 ml) to this product.
The NaOH solution was added 20% until the solution became strong base.
The basic solution was extracted using CH2Cl2 (it is 2 times about 10 ml 20 ml).
When the combined extract was dried on Na2SO4 and the solvent was removed under vacuum, the desired product was acquired as transparent oil (0.114 g, yield 68%).

Compound 134
The compound 133 (0.08 g, 0.12 mmol) is melt|dissolved in CHCl3 (5 ml) and MeOH (5 ml),
The amino imino sulfonic acid (0.045 g, 0.36 mmol) was added, and suspension was stirred for 12 hours.
The solvent was removed under vacuum and residue was melt|dissolved in 1 M HCl (6 ml) and H2O (10 ml).
Et2O (it is 3 times about 5 ml) wash|cleaned the solution, and the NaOH solution was dripped 20% until the solution became strong base.
CH2Cl2 (it is 4 times about 5 ml) extracted the basic liquid mixture.
When it was made to dry on anhydrous Na2SO4 and the combined extract was concentrated in vacuum, the desired product was acquired as white glass (0.087 g, yield 91%).
Compound 135
NaN3(0.0167 g, 0.256 mmol) was added after melt|dissolving the mesylate originating in 23(0.092 g, 0.128 mmol) in DMSO (2 ml).
Suspension was heated at 70 degreeC for 12 hours.
H2O (20 ml) was added to cooled suspension, and EtOAc/hexane (1:1) (it is 3 times about 10 ml 20 ml) extracted the liquid mixture.
Salt water (30 ml) wash|cleans the combined extract,
It is made to dry on anhydrous Na2SO4.
When concentrated under vacuum, the product was acquired as pale yellow oil (0.081 g, yield 95%).
The tetra-azide (0.081 g, 0.12 mmol) was melt|dissolved in THF (5 ml) and EtOH (10 ml).
The Lindlar catalyst (30 mg) was added and suspension was shaken under H2 (50 psi) for 12 hours.
After removing a solvent under vacuum, the silica gel chromatography (It is 2:2:1 to CH2Cl2/MeOH/28%NH3*H2O, 5:3:1, and the next.) refine|purified residue.
Et2O (it is 2 times about 10 ml) wash|cleaned the solution obtained by adding 1 M HCl (2 ml) to this product.
The NaOH solution was added to the water phase 20% until the solution became strong base.
The basic solution was extracted using CH2Cl2 (it is 2 times about 5 ml 10 ml).
When it was made to dry on anhydrous Na2SO4 and the combined extract was concentrated under vacuum, the desired product was acquired as colorless oil (0.044 g, yield 64%).

Example 15
The test of the compound by Gram-negative bacteria
MIC and a MBC measurement
Whole:
Microorganisms: The reference|standard strain|stump|stock was purchased from the bacto roll disk of American Type Culture Collection (Rockville, Maryland state) or a Difco laboratories (Detroit, Michigan state).
The following specific ATCC strain|stump|stocks were used.
10798 colon_bacillus|E._coli, 25922 colon_bacillus|E._coli, the 13883 Klebsiella pneumonia bacillus (Klebsiella pneumoniae),
27853 Psudomonas aeruginosa (Pseudomonas aeruginosa), 14028 Salmonella typhimurium (Salmonella typhimurium),
29212 Enterococcus faecalis (Enterococcus faecalis),
25923 Staphylococcus aureus (Staphylococcus aureus), 19615 Streptococcus pyogenes (Streptococcus pyogenes), and a 90028 Candida albicans (Candida albicans).
The bacteria strain was maintained on the Mueller-Hinton agar plate, and the Candida albicans (Candida albicans) was maintained on the Sabourand dextrose agar plate.

Trypsin degradation soybean juice (TBS) melt|dissolves 27.5 g of the dextrose -not-containing trypsin degradation soybean juice (DIFCO Laboratories) in 1 liter deionized water,
It sterilized and created at 121 degreeC for 15 minutes.
Solid agar (TSA) plate melt|dissolves 6.4 g of trypsin degradation soybean juice, and 12-g agar (The thing of the refined grade, Fischer Scientific) in 800 mL deionized water,
Sterilization treatment was carried out at 121 degreeC for 20 minute(s), and it created.
Next, the aliquot (20 mL) of the homogeneous solution was inject|poured into sterilized plastics Petri dishes (100*15mm, Fisher Scientific).
The solution of the compound melt|dissolved in the sterilized water which a suitable quantity deionized, and ultrafiltered and created each HCl salt.

The typical method which measures MIC and a MBC value
From the culture incubated at 37 degreeC in TSB for 24 hours, suspension containing colon_bacillus|E._coli (ATCC 10798) of -10 <6>CFU (colony forming unit) / mL was prepared.
It added to the test tube containing the call acid derivative which changed the density|concentration so that aliquot 1mL of this suspension might be increased step by step with 1 mL TSB and/or an erythromycin, or a novobiocin.
In this sensitivity experiment, the erythromycin or the novobiocin was added 15 minutes afterward from the call acid derivative.
Rest culture|cultivation was performed for this sample at 37 degreeC for 24 hours.
The turbidity of the sample was determined by measuring the light absorbency in 760 nm (HP 8453 UV-Visible Chemstation, Hewett Packard).
Furthermore, the aliquot obtained from each sample without turbidity to the extent that it can measure is on TSA plate, and it carried out the secondary culture.
(The aliquot was diluted so that it might be set to 300 or less CFU.).
After incubating overnight, the colony increased by the secondary-culture thing was counted, and the number of CFU/mL contained in a sample was computed.
The computed value was compared with the number of CFU/mL of the first inoculum.
After incubating a MIC value for 24 hours, it determined whether it as or reduced with the constant number of CFU/mL as a density|concentration of the investigated compound.
The MBC value was determined as lowest density|concentration that can survive 0.1% or less of the investigated compound of the original bacterial suspension.

Example 16
Authentication of film|membrane non-permeability of a call acid derivative
The present inventors clarified that a call acid derivative increased the permeability|transmittance of outside-film|membrane of Gram-negative bacteria using the method described in J. M. Shupp, S. E. Travis, L. B. Price, R. F. Shand, P. Keim, Rapid Bacterial Permeabilization Reagent Useful For Enzyme Assays, Biotechniques, 1995, vol. 19, 18-20.
Value (The permeability|transmittance of outside-film|membrane which accept|permits that luciferin enters into a cell is shown.) of the half of largest light emission is [ 2 ] 33 micrograms/mL about 7 micrograms/mL and 10.
These values respond|correspond to MIC measured about 2 and 10.

Result
It is known that PMB has film|membrane permeability and a bactericidal characteristic.
PMB has a hydrophobic acyl group, and D amino acid and the macrocyclic heptapeptide containing four diaminobutyric acid (DAB) residues.
One of the DAB side chains is concerned in formation of a huge ring, and other three side chains are still free amines.
Thus, PMB has a row|line|column of the amine orient|assigned to a surface with the one side of a hydrophobic scaffold structure, i.e., a plane.
It is suggested to specific arrangement|positioning required in order to couple|bond the main roles of a huge ring with the lipid A part of LPS that it is orient|assigning an amine group.
The relative spatial directionality of such primary amine groups is the same as the case of PMB also in a call acid derivative.

By the stereochemical difference in a steroid structure, the active difference in a call acid derivative (compare 2, 8, Table 1, 2, and 6 and 7) arises.
A MIC value becomes low rather than the compound in which the compound which has the guanidine group couple|bonded with steroid contains an amine group (Compare 1, 2, 4, and 5 and compare Table 1- 8.).
The length of the chain|strand between an amine group or a guanidine group, and a steroid structure also affects it active (compare 1-3, Table 1, 2, and 6 and 7).
The chain|strand of ester between an amine group and a steroid structure has a MIC value higher than the corresponding compound containing the chain|strand of ether (compare 1, 2, 6, 7, and Table 1 and 2).

The group couple|bonded with C-20 of frame|skeleton or C-24 also affects the activity of a call acid derivative.
When long carbon chain has couple|bonded with steroid through an ether bond by C-24, compared with the compound which has couple|bonded the hydroxyl group with C-24, MIC of the compound will become small (Compare 2, 9, 10, Table 1, 2, and 6 and 7.).
When the short chain|strand of carbon or oxygen has couple|bonded with C-20, the MIC value of a call acid derivative will become small (compare 10, 11, and Table 1 and 2).
The call acid derivative covalently bonded makes the activity of the compound increase (compare 10, 12, and Table 1 and 2).

The capability to permeabilize|transparentize outside-film|membrane
It investigated about the antibiotic activity of the compounds 11, 106, 108-114 (FIG. 1).
They tested also about the capability to make into permeability|transmittance outside-film|membrane of Gram-negative bacteria which causes the sensitization with respect to hydrophobic antibiotics which cannot pass outside-film|membrane.
Permeabilization|transparentization of outside-film|membrane was measured using the erythromycin and the novobiocin.
These antibiotics are inactive to Gram-negative bacteria because of the obstacle formed of outside-film|membrane of Gram-negative bacteria with respect to Gram-positive bacteria although it was active.

Almost all experiment was conducted using E.. coli K-12 strain ATCC 10798;
However, in order to authenticate that the activity of a call acid derivative is not species specific, the activity of the selected compound was measured also about Psudomonas aeruginosa (Pseudomonas aeruginosa)(ATCC 27853).
MIC of the erythromycin with respect to colon_bacillus|E._coli (ATCC 10798) and the novobiocin was measured by 70 and >500 microg/ml.
The threshold value measured value regarding permeabilization|transparentization was a density|concentration of the call acid derivative required in order to reduce an erythromycin or MIC in any one of a novobiocin to 1 microg/ml.

The result of MIC, MBC, and a permeabilization|transparentization (based on erythromycin) measurement is shown in FIG. 2 (In FIG. 2, the compound A is polymyxin B nonapeptide.).
As shown in FIG. 2, MIC and the MBC value of the compound fell dramatically as the length of the side chain expand|extended from C-17 increased.
The clear role of a hydrophobic steroidal side chain is accelerating|stimulating adhesion on a film|membrane, and the self propulsion transport after the first time association|meeting with outside-film|membrane of Gram-negative bacteria (it shows in FIG. 3 like).
Permeabilization|transparentization of outside-film|membrane occurs as a result of association|meeting with the lipid A on the lobule of the outer side of a film|membrane.
Only by permeabilization|transparentization of outside-film|membrane, a cell death was not caused, but this has suggested that outside-film|membrane must be passed, in order for a compound to kill bacteria.
Since a compound has lethal activity, the passage ability of outside-film|membrane and the destructive ability of the cytoplasmic membrane by it are required.

The compound which does not have a hydrophobic side chain has a weak germicidal action so that it may be recognized.
Although these compounds can make outside-film|membrane permeability|transmittance (That is, it associates with the lipid A on the lobule of the outer side of a film|membrane.), the postulate that outside-film|membrane cannot be passed is built up.

The fraction inhibitory concentration (FIC) value of the compound was calculated using an erythromycin and a novobiocin as a secondary compound.
The compound showed less than 0.5 FIC value by having made 114 into the exception regarding the erythromycin, and there also existed a value close|similar to 0.05 in inside (Table 9).

The detail of the test using a novobiocin is similarly shown in Table 9.
The fact that the result depended on an erythromycin and a novobiocin was equivalent has shown that the activity of a call acid derivative is not dependent to antibiotics.
The similar tendency was recognized also about colon_bacillus|E._coli (ATCC 10798) and Psudomonas aeruginosa (P. aeruginosa)(ATCC 27853),
However,
As it estimated|forecast, Psudomonas aeruginosa (P. aeruginosa) was resistance from colon_bacillus|E._coli.
These results have suggested that the activity of the investigated compound is not dependent as a species.

The compound which has the hydrophobic alkylamino alkyl side chain was prepared (the compounds 133 and 134, FIG. 4).
As it recognized about the other compound, when the guanidine group was incorporated (134), the activity of the call acid derivative increased compared with the compound containing a primary amine.
As a control, 135 (FIG. 4) which does not have a hydrophobic side chain was prepared.
MIC of the control|contrast (135) was comparatively high as expected similarly to MBC (FIG. 5).
by contrast, MIC of 133 and 134 was very low -- those activity was actually equal to PMB.
Especially 133, 134, and MBC of PMB were very similar with MIC.
Namely, a threshold value density|concentration
WHEREIN:
These compounds killed all the bacteria in a solution.

As further means to authenticate the film|membrane destructive ability of the call acid derivatives 133 and 134, the cytolysis assay based on luciferin/luciferase was used.
(The passage of description to Willardson (Willardson), Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 1998, 64, 1006, Schaap (Schupp), and Biotechniques 1995, 19, 18).
This assay
WHEREIN:
Colon_bacillus|E._coli containing the plasmid which codes an induction type luciferase was incubated with the inducer (toluene),
Then, it processed with the melt|dissolution buffer solution containing one either and Triton X-100 of PMB or a call acid derivative.
Next, luciferin and ATP were added.
Light emission occurred by cytolysis.
The density|concentration of the film|membrane destructive substance (PMB and call acid derivative) was changed, and obtained light emission was measured.
Light emission was not recognized when a film|membrane destructive substance did not exist.

A density|concentration required for MIC and half-largest light emission of 133, 134, and PMB is shown in FIG. 6.
The activity of the compounds 133 and 134 is equal to the activity of PMB in the light emission assay similarly to the case of a MIC value.

The effect|action of sulfate group
In order that presence of the sulfate group of C-24 in a call acid derivative might observe whether the activity of a compound is made to increase, 132 (it shows in FIG. 7) was investigated.
MIC of 132 by colon_bacillus|E._coli (ATCC 10798) was 60 microg/ml.
The density|concentration required in order to reduce MIC of an erythromycin to 1 microg/ml was 4.0 microg/ml about the same strain|stump|stock.
The antibiotic activity and permeabilization|transparentization activity of 132 were lower than the activity of the alcohol 110 (it shows in FIG. 1) which is a parent compound.

Further experiment
Further experiment was conducted using compound 1, 2, 5, 106, 10, 112, 133 and 134.
About the typical strain|stump|stock of a Gram negative and a gram-positive living organism|raw_food, MIC and MBC data of these compounds are shown in Table 10.
For the comparison objective, MIC of PMB by various living organism|raw_foods is also measured, and it shows in Table 10.

Compound 1, 2, 5, 106, 10, 112, 133 and 134 other than PMB share other steroid antibiotics and a certain characteristics.
For example, squalamine contains a steroid nucleus and a polyamine side chain.
(Moore, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1993, 90, 1354-1358).
It is advocated that squalamine is incorporated in a lipid bilayer and destroys a bacteria film|membrane.
Squalamine
WHEREIN:
Polar polyamine functionality exists in the distal terminal of a molecule|numerator, and leaves a hydrophobic core.
In 1, 2, 5, 106, 10, 112, 133 and 134, an amine exists in the one side of steroid and gives an amphiphilic compound externally.
1, 2, 5, 106, 10, 112, 133 and a series of another compounds relevant to 134 contain in C -24 position the call acid derivative which has an amine (for example, 140 of FIG. 7).
By contrast [ 1, 2, 5, 106, 10, 112, 133 and 134 ], these compounds have the very weak antimicrobial activity with respect to Gram-positive bacteria, and not showing activity to Gram-negative bacteria is shown.

Call acid derivative 1, 2, 5, 106, 10, 112, 133 and 134 show an active width|variety, and there exist some which show MIC below the microgram/ml in inside.
MIC and a MBC value are very similar with the most active high compound especially with respect to many living organism|raw_foods.
Probably some of compounds show the lethal activity by destruction of a cytoplasmic membrane.
Others only have a sub- lethal activity by permeabilization|transparentization of outside-film|membrane.

Although the compound (for example, 106 and 10) which lose|deletes a hydrophobic chain|strand has a high MIC value, it is an effective permeation|transmission agent of outside-film|membrane of Gram-negative bacteria.
In order that these compounds may lose|delete a hydrophobic chain|strand, they have the activity which is sub-lethal and is not lethal with respect to these bacteria.
The compound (for example, 133 and 134) which has a hydrophobic chain|strand has lethal activity.

It has suggested that they can act as a film|membrane destructive substance in call acid derivative 1, 2, 5, 106, 10, 112, 133 and the hemoclasis of 134, and that those antimicrobial activity is probably accompanied by a destruction of membrane.
Regarding Gram-negative bacteria, an inactive target is estimate|forecasted as it is a cytoplasmic membrane.
A compound like 106 and 10 cannot pass outside-film|membrane effectively, and does not show lethal activity.
The hydrophobic chain|strand in 133 and 134 may accelerate|stimulate the self propulsion transport which passes along outside-film|membrane, and may destroy a cytoplasmic membrane by it.

As for the result shown in Table 10, presence of a hydrophobic chain|strand has shown that takes active lethal and it is not so important with respect to Gram-positive bacteria.
Even if it is not satisfying the requirements which pass outside-film|membrane, the compound which lose|deletes the hydrophobic chain|strand expand|extended from C-17 can kill Gram-positive bacteria effectively.

The length of various coupling|bondings was investigated and the amine or the optimal space|interval of the guanidine group was determined from steroid.
It became clear that three carbon bonds produced a more effective compound than the compound of two carbon bonds.
(For example, MIC of 1 is compared with MIC of two.).
The increase in the antibiotic activity acquired when a guanidine group is substituted by an amine has suggested the central role of an amine / guanidine phosphoric acid interaction.

The characteristic of the group couple|bonded with the steroid structure by C-17 exerted influence on the activity of the compound with respect to Gram-negative bacteria large.
For example, the difference of MIC regarding 106, 10, and 112 and a MBC value was remarkable.
Also in MIC and the MCB value of 2 and 5, this tendency was recognized compared with the value of 133 and 134.
(This comparison
WHEREIN:
The benzyl group of 2 and 5 is estimate|forecasted as hydrophobicity is lower than the octyl chain|strand recognized in 133 and 134.).
The influence of the group couple|bonded with steroid by C-17 is not so remarkable in Gram-positive bacteria, and 5 and 134 have a similar MIC value with respect to Staphylococcus aureus (Staphylococcus aureus), for example.

In order to measure permeabilization|transparentization, compound 1, 2, 5, 106, 10, 112, 133 and the FIC value of 134 by the erythromycin, the novobiocin, and a rifampicin were determined.
The density|concentration of the call acid derivative required in order to block|prevent bacteria growth of Gram-negative bacteria was determined using 0.5 of these antibiotics, 1.0, or the density|concentration of 3.0 microg/ml.
A density|concentration required for bacteria growth blockage|prevention and a FIC value are shown to Tables 11-13.
The MIC value of a compound is not directly correlated with an interesting thing at the permeabilization|transparentization ability of outside-film|membrane.
For example, although the compounds 106 and 10 have a comparatively high MIC value, they are forceful permeabilization|transparentization agents.
Almost all of the compound showed less than 0.5 FIC value, and there also existed less than 0.03 compound in inside.
The call acid derivatives (namely, 5, 133, and 134) which produce a comparatively high FIC value are forceful antibiotics in itself.

Ester and the amide|amido side chain
The compound which has the further compound, for example, amide|amido, and an ester side chain was investigated.
The compounds 203b, 6, and 210a (scheme 12) showed forceful synergism with an erythromycin and a novobiocin (Table 14).
In a series of triester (203a, 203b, 6 and 7), (beta) alanine origin compound is highly active than the compound originating in glycine.
The substitution of C24 hardly exerted influence on the activity of these compounds (203b and 7, and comparison).

Probably triamide 209 a-c (scheme 12) was for the structural constraint given by the amide bond, or its activity was lower than ester.
When substituted by C24 regarding the triamide, significant influence was exerted on the activity of the compound.
(It compares with 209a and 210a, and is Table 14.).
This series
WHEREIN:
The glycine derivative was highly active than corresponding (beta) alanine derivative.

The relative lack of the synergism shown with the lysine derivative|guide_body may be caused to the length of a side chain.
As a control, the derivative|guide_body of 209c which lose|deletes the compound 211 (FIG. 8) and the (alpha)- amino group was prepared.
This compound had activity weaker than 209c as a permeabilization|transparentization agent.
It was authenticated that the compound 206 is not also effective as a permeabilization|transparentization agent.
From these results, it is suggested that the optimal length of the coupling|bonding between steroid and an amine functional group is from zero to six atoms.

Another aspect
All the characteristics disclosed to this specification are combinable with arbitrary combinations.
You may substitute each characteristics disclosed by this specification with the same, the equivalent, or another characteristics that fulfill|perform the similar objective.
Thus, especially each characteristics disclosed unless it wrote in a separate paragraph and stated are mere examples in a series of general equivalent characteristics or the similar characteristics.

The expert can confirm the essential characteristics of this invention easily from said description, and it is possible to perform a deformation|transformation and modification of the versatility of this invention so that this invention may adapt a various using method and conditions, without deviating from the mind and range.
For example, the salt, ester, ether, and amide|amido of the novel steroid compound disclosed to this specification are contained in the scope of the present invention.
Thus, another aspect is also contained in this claim.
